name: FeedingPracticesOntology
description: An ontology for classifying infant feeding practices in clinical text.

categories.definition: Terms indicating that breast milk is the primary or exclusive source of nutrition, whether directly from the breast or via expressed milk.

terms.definition: Feeding an infant directly from the breast.
terms.example_usage: Mother is breastfeeding the newborn every 2 hours.

terms.definition: Feeding an infant only breast milk, with no addition of formula or other supplements except for vitamins or medications.
terms.example_usage: Infant is exclusively breastfed for the first 6 months.

terms.definition: An inclusive term for feeding an infant from the chest; typically used by individuals who do not identify with the term 'breastfeeding.'
terms.example_usage: He is chestfeeding his newborn to support bonding and nutrition.

terms.definition: The practice of receiving breast milk from another lactating individual through informal sharing arrangements.
terms.example_usage: The mother opted for milk sharing with another lactating parent in her community.

terms.definition: Milk produced by the human breast, regardless of delivery method (breast, bottle, tube, etc.).
terms.example_usage: The mother brought expressed breastmilk in labeled bottles.

terms.definition: The act of expressing breast milk using hand expression or a breast pump.
terms.example_usage: She performs breastmilk expression several times a day to store milk for later use.

categories.definition: Terms indicating that infant formula is the primary or exclusive source of nutrition (or references to specific infant formula products).

terms.definition: Commercially prepared formula designed to feed infants as an alternative or supplement to breast milk.
terms.example_usage: Patient is on infant formula for supplemental feedings.

terms.definition: A popular brand of infant formula.
terms.example_usage: Similac was used exclusively during the first week.

terms.definition: A well-known brand of infant formula available in various formulations.
terms.example_usage: Switched from Enfamil to a specialized formula due to intolerance.

terms.definition: A brand offering infant formula and other baby food products.
terms.example_usage: Gerber formula was introduced at two months.

terms.definition: An organic infant formula brand.
terms.example_usage: Mother prefers Earthâ€™s Best formula for organic certification.

terms.definition: A specialized infant formula designed to meet the nutritional needs of premature or low-birth-weight infants.
terms.example_usage: NeoSure recommended for infant born preterm.

terms.definition: A specialized formula by Enfamil for premature infants.
terms.example_usage: The NICU provided EnfaCare due to prematurity.

categories.definition: Terms that could indicate feeding, collection, or pumping without clearly specifying whether it is breast milk or formula; or partially relevant to both contexts.

terms.definition: Feeding an infant with a bottle, which could contain either formula or expressed breast milk.
terms.example_usage: Baby was bottlefed overnight due to maternal rest needs.

terms.definition: Collection of milk that may be used for feeding, sharing, or storage; the context may not specify if actual breastfeeding occurs.
terms.example_usage: She has breast milk collection bags in the refrigerator.

terms.definition: Using a pump to extract milk from breasts; does not always clarify whether the milk will be fed or discarded.
terms.example_usage: The mother performed breast pumping but also supplemented with formula.

terms.definition: A fortifying additive often used with breast milk for premature infants; ambiguous because it can introduce formula-like components into breast milk.
terms.example_usage: Human milk fortifier was added to expressed breast milk for additional calories.

categories.definition: Terms related to feeding difficulties, techniques, or anatomical issues without specifying breast vs. formula feeding.

terms.definition: Discomfort or pain in nipples, common during or after feeding sessions.
terms.example_usage: Patient reports tender nipples after feeding attempts.

terms.definition: Physical cracking or fissures in the nipple area, often associated with breastfeeding but not exclusively.
terms.example_usage: Cracked nipples noted on exam, recommended topical treatment.

terms.definition: A cream commonly used to treat or prevent nipple soreness or cracking, particularly in breastfeeding individuals.
terms.example_usage: Applying lanolin between feedings to soothe nipple pain.

terms.definition: Manual technique for expressing breast milk, but not explicitly indicating exclusive breastmilk usage.
terms.example_usage: Hand expression taught in postpartum class.

terms.definition: A specific hold used in breastfeeding, but the term alone may not confirm actual feeding type.
terms.example_usage: Mother instructed on using the football hold to improve latch.

terms.definition: General issues with feeding, which could involve either breast or formula feeding.
terms.example_usage: Infant exhibits feeding difficulties due to cleft palate.

terms.definition: Insufficient growth in an infant, potentially linked to suboptimal intake of breast milk or formula.
terms.example_usage: Poor weight gain prompts evaluation of feeding method.

terms.definition: Nasogastric tube used for enteral feeding; can be used for either breast milk or formula.
terms.example_usage: NG tube inserted for supplementary feeding.

terms.definition: Method of feeding using a tube directly into the stomach; used for both breast milk or formula.
terms.example_usage: Gavage feeding established post-surgery.

terms.definition: Challenges with an infant latching onto the breast; however, does not definitively indicate exclusive breastfeeding.
terms.example_usage: Mother reports latch difficulties resulting in partial formula supplementation.

classificationRules.ExclusiveBreastfeeding: If clinical text contains one or more 'Breastfeeding' terms (or synonyms) and no 'Formula Feeding' terms, label as Exclusive Breastfeeding.
classificationRules.ExclusiveFormulaFeeding: If clinical text contains one or more 'Formula Feeding' terms (or synonyms) and no 'Breastfeeding' terms, label as Exclusive Formula Feeding.
classificationRules.MixedFeeding: If clinical text contains at least one 'Breastfeeding' term and at least one 'Formula Feeding' term, label as Mixed Feeding.
classificationRules.None: If clinical text does not contain terms from either 'Breastfeeding' or 'Formula Feeding' categories, label as None.
classificationRules.AmbiguousHandling: If only 'Ambiguous' terms appear, further context is recommended. By default, if no clear Breastfeeding or Formula Feeding terms appear, label as None.
classificationRules.ExplanationNote: Terms in 'Feeding-Related' category alone do not determine classification unless accompanied by 'Breastfeeding' or 'Formula Feeding' terms. They serve as contextual or supportive evidence.
